H0.text: Pressure increases when the number of gas molecules in the same volume container increases.

H1.text: Friction is increased by an increase in the number of gas molecules in the same volume container.

H2.text: Energy increases when the number of gas molecules in the same volume container increases.

H3.text: Power increases when the number of gas molecules in the same volume container increases.

A4.text: The ideal gas law relates pressure, volume, and temperature through the equation pV = nRT, where n is the amount of substance. An increase in n, with constant volume and temperature, leads to an increase in pressure.

A5.text: From the derivation P0 = (1/3)nmvÂ², pressure is directly proportional to the number of molecules (n), assuming velocity (v) and mass (m) are constant.
